abstract.text: A search is conducted for new physics in a final state containing a photon and missing transverse momentum in proton-proton collisions at √ s = 13 TeV.
The data collected by the CMS experiment at the CERN LHC correspond to an integrated luminosity of 12.9 fb −1 .
No deviations are observed relative to the predictions of the standard model.
The results are interpreted as exclusion limits on the dark matter production cross sections and parameters in models containing extra spatial dimensions.
Improved limits are set with respect to previous searches using the monophoton final state.
In particular, the limits on the extra dimension model parameters are the most stringent to date in this channel.

body_text.text: The CMS collaboration 19 1 Introduction
One of the most intriguing open questions in physics is the nature of dark matter (DM).
While DM is thought to be the dominant nonbaryonic contribution to the matter density of the universe [1], its detection and identification in terrestrial and spaceborne experiments remains elusive.

At the CERN LHC, the DM particles may be produced in high-energy proton-proton collisions, if the DM particles interact with the standard model (SM) quarks or gluons via new couplings at the electroweak scale [2,3].

Although DM particles cannot be directly detected at the LHC, their production could be inferred from an observation of events with a large transverse momentum imbalance (missing transverse momentum, p miss T , defined in section 2).
Another highly important issue is the hierarchy problem, which involves the large energy gap between the electroweak (M EW ) and Planck (M Pl ) scales [4].
Proposed solutions to this problem include theories with large extra dimensions, such as the model of Arkani-Hamed, Dimopoulos, Dvali (ADD) [5,6].

The ADD model postulates that there exist n compactified extra dimensions in which gravitons can propagate freely and that the true scale (M D ) of the gravitational interaction in this 4+n dimensional space-time is of the same order as M EW .
The compactification scale R of the additional dimensions is related to the two gravitational scales by M 2 Pl ∼ R n M n+2 D .
For M D ∼ M EW , the cases n = 1 and n = 2 are ruled out or strongly disfavored by various observations [6], while cases n ≥ 3 remain  Figure 1.

Leading-order diagrams of the simplified DM model (left), electroweak-DM effective interaction (center), and graviton (G) production in the ADD model (right), with a final state of γ and large p miss T .
to be probed, for example, by collider experiments.
The compactification scale R is much greater than 1/M EW for a wide range of n, leading to a near-continuous mass spectrum of Kaluza-Klein graviton states.
Although the gravitons would not be observed directly at the LHC, their production would be manifest as events broadly distributed in p miss T .
In generic models of DM and graviton production, various SM particles can recoil against these undetected particles, producing a variety of final states with significant p miss T .
The monophoton, or γ + p miss T , final state has the advantage of being identifiable with high efficiency and purity.
In DM production through a vector or axial vector mediator, a photon can be radiated from incident quarks (figure 1 left).
Models of this process have been developed by the CMS-ATLAS Dark Matter Forum [7].
It is also possible that the DM sector couples preferentially to the electroweak sector, leading to an effective interaction qq → Z/γ * → γχχ [8], where χ is the DM particle (figure 1 center).
In ADD graviton production, the graviton can couple directly to the photon (figure 1 right) or to a quark.
In this paper, we examine final states containing large p miss T in the presence of a photon with large transverse momentum (p T ), and search for an excess of events over the SM prediction.
Data collected by the CMS experiment in 2016 with an integrated luminosity of 12.9 fb −1 are analyzed.
Results are interpreted in the context of these three models.
The primary irreducible background for the γ + p miss T signal is SM Z boson production associated with a photon, Z(→ νν) + γ.

Other SM backgrounds include W(→ ν) + γ (having a final state photon, and a lepton that escapes detection), W → ν (where is misidentified as a photon), γ + jets, quantum chromodynamics (QCD) multijet events (with a jet misidentified as a photon), ttγ, VVγ (where V refers to a W or a Z boson), Z(→ ) + γ, and noncollision sources, such as beam halo interactions and detector noise.
A previous search in the γ + p miss T final state using pp collisions at √ s = 8 TeV, corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 19.6 fb −1 , was reported by the CMS experiment in ref.
The ATLAS experiment has also reported a similar search in 36.1 fb −1 of pp collisions at √ s = 13 TeV [10].
The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

The central feature of the CMS apparatus is a superconducting solenoid of 6 m internal diameter, providing a magnetic field of 3.8 T. Within the solenoid volume are a silicon pixel and strip tracker, a lead tungstate crystal electromagnetic calorimeter (ECAL), and a brass JHEP10(2017)073

body_text.text: and scintillator hadron calorimeter (HCAL), each composed of a barrel (|η| < 1.48) and two endcap (1.48 < |η| < 3.00) sections, where η is the pseudorapidity.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Extensive forward calorimetry complements the coverage provided by the barrel and endcap detectors.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Muons are measured in gas-ionization detectors embedded in the steel flux-return yoke outside the solenoid.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: An energy resolution of about 1% is reached within the barrel section of the ECAL for unconverted or late-converting photons with p T ≥ 60 GeV.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: The remaining barrel photons have a resolution of about 1.3% up to a pseudorapidity of |η| = 1, rising to about 2.5% at |η| = 1.4 [11].
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: The time resolution of photons at the ECAL is <200 ps for depositions >10 GeV.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: In the η-φ plane, where φ is the azimuthal angle, and for |η| < 1.48, the HCAL cells map onto 5×5 arrays of ECAL crystals to form calorimeter towers projecting radially outward from the center of the detector.

The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Events of interest are selected using a two-tiered trigger system [13].
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: The first level (L1), composed of custom hardware processors, uses information from the calorimeters and muon detectors to select events at a rate of around 100 kHz within a time interval of less than 4 µs.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: The second level, known as the high-level trigger (HLT), consists of a farm of processors running a version of the full event reconstruction software optimized for fast processing, and reduces the event rate to less than 1 kHz before data storage.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Event reconstruction is performed using a particle-flow (PF) technique [14,15], which reconstructs and identifies individual particles using an optimized combination of information from all subdetectors.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: The energy of charged hadrons is determined from a combination of the track momentum and the corresponding ECAL and HCAL energies, corrected for the combined response function of the calorimeters.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: The energy of neutral hadrons is obtained from the corresponding corrected ECAL and HCAL energies.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Muon identification and momentum measurements are performed by combining the information from the inner trackers and outer muon chambers.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: The PF candidates in each event are clustered into jets via the anti-k t algorithm [16] with a distance parameter of 0.4.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Jet energies, computed from a simple sum of 4-momenta of the constituent PF candidates, are corrected to account for the contributions from particles associated with additional interactions within the same or nearby bunch crossings (pileup), as well as to compensate for the nonlinearities in the measured particle energies.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Jet energy corrections are obtained from simulation, and are confirmed through in situ measurements of the energy momentum balance in dijet and photon + jet events.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: The uncorrected missing transverse momentum vector ( p miss T ) is defined as the negative vector sum of the transverse momenta of all PF candidates in an event.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: This quantity is adjusted with the difference of uncorrected and corrected jets for a consistent and more accurate missing momentum measurement [17].
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: The magnitude of p miss T is referred to as the missing transverse momentum, p miss T .
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: The reconstruction of photons and electrons begins with the identification of clusters of energy deposited in the ECAL with little or no observed energy in the corresponding HCAL region.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: For each candidate cluster, the reconstruction algorithm searches for hits in JHEP10 (2017)073the pixel and strip trackers that can be associated with the cluster.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Such associated hits are called electron seeds, and are used to initiate a special track reconstruction based on a Gaussian sum filter [18,19], which is optimized for electron tracks.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: A "seed veto" removes photon candidates with an associated electron seed.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Selections based on calorimetric information and isolation are applied to distinguish photons from electromagnetic (EM) showers caused by hadrons.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: The calorimetric requirements for photons comprise H/E < 0.05 and σ ηη < 0.0102, where H/E is the ratio of hadronic to EM energy deposition.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: The variable σ ηη , described in detail in ref.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: [11], represents the width of the electromagnetic shower in the η direction, which is generally larger in showers from hadronic activity.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: For a photon candidate to be considered as isolated, scalar sums of the transverse momenta of PF charged hadrons, neutral hadrons, and photons within a cone of ∆R = √ (∆η) 2 + (∆φ) 2 < 0.3 around the candidate photon must individually fall below the bounds defined for 80% signal efficiency.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Only the PF candidates that do not overlap with the EM shower of the candidate photon are included in the isolation sums.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Each PF charged hadron is reconstructed from a track and can be associated with an interaction vertex it originates from.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Therefore, the isolation sum over PF charged hadrons should be computed using only the candidates sharing an interaction vertex with the photon candidate.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: However, because photon candidates are not reconstructed from tracks, their vertex association is ambiguous.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: When an incorrect vertex is assigned, photon candidates that are not isolated can appear otherwise.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: To mitigate the rate for accepting nonisolated candidates as photon candidates, the maximum charged hadron isolation value over all vertex hypotheses (worst isolation) is used.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Another consequence of calorimetry-driven reconstruction is that stray ECAL clusters produced by mechanisms other than pp collisions can be misidentified as photons.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: In particular, beam halo muons that accompany proton beams and penetrate the detector longitudinally, and the interaction of particles in the ECAL photodetectors ("ECAL spikes") have been found to produce spurious photon candidates at nonnegligible rates.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: To reject these backgrounds, the ECAL signal in the seed crystal of the photon cluster is required to be within ±3 ns of the arrival time expected for particles originating from a collision.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: In addition, the candidate cluster must comprise more than a single ECAL crystal.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Furthermore, the maximum of the total energy along all possible paths of beam halo particles passing through the cluster is calculated for each photon candidate.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: This quantity, referred to as the halo total energy, is required to be below a threshold defined to retain 95% of the true photons, while rejecting 80% of the potential halo clusters.
body_text.section: The CMS detector and candidate reconstruction

body_text.text: Event selection
The integrated luminosity of the analyzed data sample, derived from a preliminary measurement using the method described in [20], is (12.9 ± 0.8) fb −1 .
body_text.section: Event selection

body_text.text: The data sample is collected with a single-photon trigger that requires at least one photon candidate with p T > 165 GeV.
body_text.section: Event selection

body_text.text: The photon candidate must have H/E < 0.1, to reject jets.
body_text.section: Event selection

body_text.text: The photon energy reconstructed in the trigger is less precise relative to that derived later in the offline selection.
body_text.section: Event selection

body_text.text: Therefore, the thresholds in the trigger on both H/E and p γ T , where
body_text.section: Event selection

body_text.text: the photon p T , are less restrictive than their offline counterparts.
body_text.section: Event selection

body_text.text: The trigger efficiency is measured to be about 98% for events passing the analysis selection with p γ T > 175 GeV.
body_text.section: Event selection

body_text.text: From the recorded data, events are selected by requiring p miss T > 170 GeV and at least one photon with p γ T > 175 GeV in the fiducial region of the ECAL barrel (|η| < 1.44).
body_text.section: Event selection

body_text.text: Events are rejected if the minimum opening angle between p miss T and any of the four highest transverse momenta jets, ∆φ( p miss T , p jet T ), is less than 0.5.
body_text.section: Event selection

body_text.text: This requirement significantly suppresses spurious p miss T backgrounds from mismeasured jets.
body_text.section: Event selection

body_text.text: Only jets with p T > 30 GeV and |η| < 5 are considered in the ∆φ( p miss T , p jet T ) calculation.
body_text.section: Event selection

body_text.text: The candidate photon transverse momentum vector and p miss T must be separated by more than 2 radians.
body_text.section: Event selection

body_text.text: Finally, to reduce the contribution from the W(→ ν) + γ process, events are vetoed if they contain an electron or a muon with p T > 10 GeV that is separated from the photon by ∆R > 0.5.
body_text.section: Event selection

body_text.text: Signal and background modeling
The SM backgrounds and signal are modeled using both simulated events and recorded data.
body_text.section: Signal and background modeling

body_text.text: The two methods are described in the following sections.

body_text.text: Monte Carlo simulation for signal and background modeling
Monte Carlo (MC) simulation is used to model the signal and some classes of SM background events.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulation for signal and background modeling

body_text.text: For the SM backgrounds, the primary hard interaction is simulated using the MadGraph5 amc@nlo version 2.2.2 [21] or pythia8.212 [22] generators employing the NNPDF 3.0 [23] leading-order (LO) parton distribution function (PDF) set at the strong coupling value α S = 0.130.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulation for signal and background modeling

body_text.text: Parton showering and hadronization are provided in pythia8.212 through the underlying-event tune CUETP8M1 [24].
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulation for signal and background modeling

body_text.text: Multiple minimum-bias events are overlaid on the primary interaction to model the distribution of pileup in data.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulation for signal and background modeling

body_text.text: Generated particles are processed through the full Geant4-based simulation of the CMS detector [25,26].
body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulation for signal and background modeling

body_text.text: For the DM signal hypothesis, MC simulation samples are produced with Mad-Graph5 amc@nlo 2.2.2, requiring p γ T > 130 GeV and |η γ | < 2.5.

body_text.section: Monte Carlo simulation for signal and background modeling

body_text.text: Background estimation using recorded data
An important background consists of W → eν events in which the electron is misidentified as a photon.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: The misidentification occurs because of an inefficiency in seeding electron tracks.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: A seeding efficiency of = 0.977 ± 0.002 for electrons with p T > 160 GeV is measured in data using a tag-and-probe technique in Z → ee events, and is verified with MC simulation.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: Misidentified electron events are modeled by a proxy sample of electron events, defined in data by requiring an ECAL cluster with a pixel seed.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: The proxy events must otherwise pass the same criteria used to select signal candidate events.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: The number of electron proxy events is then scaled by (1 − )/ to yield an estimated contribution of 52.7±4.2 events from electron misidentification.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: The dominant uncertainty in this estimate is the statistical uncertainty in the measurement of .
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: Electromagnetic showers from hadronic activity can also mimic a photon signature.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: This process is estimated by counting the numbers of events in two different subsets of a lowp miss T multijet data sample.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: The first subset consists of events with a photon candidate that satisfies the signal selection criteria.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: These events contain both true photons and jets that are misidentified as photons.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: The second subset comprises events with a candidate photon that meets less stringent shower-shape requirements and inverted isolation criteria with respect to the signal candidates.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: Nearly all of the candidate photons in these events arise from JHEP10(2017)073 jet misidentification.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: The hadron misidentification ratio is defined as the ratio between the number of the misidentified events in the first subset to the total number of events in the second subset.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: The numerator is estimated by fitting the shower shape distribution of the photon candidate in the first subset with template distributions.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: For true photons, a template for the shower width is formed using simulated γ+jets events.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: For jets misidentified as photons, the template is obtained from a sample selected by inverting the charged-hadron isolation and removing the shower-shape requirement entirely.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: Once the hadron misidentification ratio is computed, it is multiplied by the number of events in the high-p miss T control sample with a photon candidate that satisfies the conditions used to select the second subset of the low-p miss T control sample.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: The product, 5.9 ± 1.7 events, is the estimate of the contribution of jet misidentification background in the signal region.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: The dominant uncertanty is systematic, and accounts for the effects of the fitting procedure, sample purity, photon candidate definition of the control samples, and the sample bias in the jet composition.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: Finally, backgrounds from beam halo and spikes in the ECAL are estimated from fits of the angular and timing distributions of the calorimeter clusters.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: Energy clusters in the ECAL due to beam halo muons are observed to concentrate around φ ∼ 0 and π, while all other processes (collision-related processes and ECAL spikes) produce photon candidates that are uniformly distributed in φ.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: The distribution of the cluster seed time provides a cross-check on this background estimate and an independent means to estimate the ECAL spikes contribution.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: Exploiting these features, a two-component fit of the φ distribution with beam halo and uniform templates, and a three-component fit of the cluster seed time using the halo, spike, and prompt-photon templates are performed.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: In both fits, the halo template is obtained by requiring high halo total energy for candidate-like photon candidates.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: The timing distribution of the spike background is obtained by inverting the shower shape requirement in the candidate photon selection.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: The results of the two fits are combined into an uncertainty-weighted average.
body_text.section: Background estimation using recorded data

body_text.text: Beam halo and spike backgrounds of 5.5 +9.3 −5.5 and 8.5 ± 6.7 events, respectively, are predicted, where the dominant uncertainty is statistical.

body_text.text: Limits on simplified dark matter models
The simplified DM models proposed by the LHC Dark Matter Forum [7] are designed to facilitate the comparison and translation of various DM search results.
body_text.section: Limits on simplified dark matter models

body_text.text: In the models considered in this analysis, Dirac DM particles couple to a vector or axial-vector mediator, which in turn couples to the SM quarks.
body_text.section: Limits on simplified dark matter models

body_text.text: Model points are identified by a set of four parameters: the DM mass m DM , the mediator mass M med , the universal mediator coupling to quarks g q , and the mediator coupling to DM particles g DM .
body_text.section: Limits on simplified dark matter models

body_text.text: In this analysis, we fix the values of g q and g DM to 0.25 and 1.0, respectively, and scan the M med -m DM plane [38].

body_text.text: Summary

Proton-proton collisions producing large missing transverse momentum and a high transverse momentum photon have been investigated to search for new phenomena, using a data set corresponding to 12.9 fb −1 of integrated luminosity recorded at √ s = 13 TeV at the CERN LHC.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: No deviations from the standard model predictions are observed.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: Constraints are set on the production cross sections for dark matter and large extra dimension gravitons at 95% confidence level, which are then translated to limits on the parameters of the individual models.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: For the simplified dark matter production models considered, the search excludes mediator masses of up to 700 GeV for low-mass dark matter.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: For an effective dimension-7 photon-dark matter contact interaction, values of Λ up to 600 GeV are excluded.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: For the ADD model with extra spatial dimensions, values of the fundamental Planck scale up to 2.31-2.49 TeV, depending on the number of extra dimensions, are excluded.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: These are the most stringent limits in the ADD model to date using the monophoton final state.
